name: LLVM
description: The LLVM Project is a collection of modular and reusable compiler and toolchain technologies.
description_good_justification: https://llvm.org/ First paragraph at the top of the page.
interact_justification:
https://llvm.org
* Links to download the software is on the top left side of the website.
* LInk to bug tracker is on the top left side of the website.
* The last paragraph on the main page has a 'getting involved' link.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/main/LICENSE.TXT>.
floss_license_justification: The majority of the project is licensed under: Apache-2.0 WITH LLVM-exception OR NCSA.  It is packaged for both Debian and Fedora when means the licenses meets their requirements.
floss_license_osi_justification: The majority of the project is licensed under: Apache-2.0 WITH LLVM-exception OR NCSA.  There are small sections of code that are licensed under other licenses (e.g. MIT, Unicode, and others), but those are all NCSA approved.
documentation_basics_justification: There are several different documentation pages for the various sub-projects, but here is the main documentation page for LLVM: https://llvm.org/docs/
documentation_interface_justification:
The full LLVM and clang API is published via doxygen at: https://llvm.org/doxygen/ and https://clang.llvm.org/doxygen/

There are a large number of binary tools distributed by this project, the command line options for these are documented on web pages, like this: https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangCommandLineReference.html and/or in man pages distributed with the software.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
Every commit included in our releases is in the public git repository: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project. We also do release candidate releases prior to final versions e.g.:
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.0-rc1
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.0-rc2
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.0-rc3
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.0-rc4
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
The current project policy is to release a new major release every six months with bug fix releases every two weeks afterwards for 10 to 12 weeks.  Example of a year's worth of releases:
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-16.0.0
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-16.0.1
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-16.0.2
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-16.0.3
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-16.0.5
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-16.0.6
* Note due to a packaging mistake, we withdrew the 17.0.0 release and replaced it with 17.0.1.
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.1
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.2
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.3
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.4
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.5
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.6
version_semver_justification: What we use is similar to Semantic Versioning, except that when we update the minor release number, that release is not backwards compatible with the previous release.  We use the minor version to indicate the ABI has changed.
version_tags_justification: We use git tags to identify each release.  e.g. https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-17.0.6
release_notes_justification:
We have started doing individual release notes for each bug fix release now:

https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-18.1.3
release_notes_vulns_justification:
We added a note about the most recent CVE to our release notes:

https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases/tag/llvmorg-18.1.3
report_responses_justification:
On March 28, 2024, I ran a query looking at all the issues in the last 12 months:

87.2% of the bugs had at least one person other than the reporter 'participate' in the bug.
49.9% of the bugs has at least two people other than the reporter 'participate' in the bug.

From what I can tell 'participate' means someone added a comment, a label, or a reaction to a bug.
enhancement_responses_justification:
We don't have a formal way to make feature requests.
TODO: See if we can determine if there are any feature requests by looking at github labels and measure our response rate.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The instructions here are for reporting a vulnerability privately: https://llvm.org/docs/Security.html#how-to-report-a-security-issue
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: We aim to respond in 2 business days: https://llvm.org/docs/Security.html#how-to-report-a-security-issue
build_justification: We provide a CMake build system for general use.  In addition, there is a GN and also a Bazel build system that can be used as an alternative to CMake in some configurations.
build_common_tools_justification: You can build the software using CMake, which is a very common tool.
build_floss_tools_justification: CMake is a FLOSS tool you can build the project with.
test_justification: The main test suites are integrated into the https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project repository.  Instructions for how to run the tests can be found in our testing guide: https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html  We have buildbots that automatically build and test the new code when it is committed: https://lab.llvm.org/buildbot/#/console
test_invocation_justification: You can run the test suite using `make check-all` or `ninja check-all` depending on which tool you are using.  See https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html
test_most_justification: As of November 2023, our tests suite covered ~85% of the clang, llvm, and lldb sub-projects.  See https://lab.llvm.org/coverage/coverage-reports/coverage/Users/buildslave/jenkins/workspace/coverage/llvm-project/index.html
test_policy_justification: We have a policy of requiring tests for bug fixes and new features: https://llvm.org/docs/DeveloperPolicy.html#test-cases
tests_are_added_justification:
Commit logs for some of our test directories:
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/commits/main/llvm/test
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/commits/main/clang/test

This is a smaller feature, but this patch for new functionality added tests: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/commit/8186e1500b1d9709f10199b7c599274f8a6f8e3a
tests_documented_added_justification: We don't really have an official change proposal policy, but we do mention n the developer policy that tests should be added for new features: https://llvm.org/docs/DeveloperPolicy.html#test-cases
warnings_justification: The project enables -Wextra and other warnings by default and also enables -Wall except when compiling with clang-cl: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/e07a2f49e3d3c13b6e9b89e0f6118652f2b2d3ac/llvm/cmake/modules/HandleLLVMOptions.cmake#L774
warnings_fixed_justification: Our latest release (17.0.6) had 9,636,137 lines of code ( cloc --include-lang="C,C++,C/C++ Header" compiler-rt/ clang-tools-extra/ libcxx libcxxabi/ libunwind/ openmp/ lld lldb polly mlir flang llvm/ bolt clang/).  In our official release builds, there were 110 warnings: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/actions/runs/7017442066/job/19094022079.  This is less that 1 per 100 lines.
warnings_strict_justification:
The project enables -Wall (in most configurations) and -Wextra by default.
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/e07a2f49e3d3c13b6e9b89e0f6118652f2b2d3ac/llvm/cmake/modules/HandleLLVMOptions.cmake#L774
know_secure_design_justification: As of 4/23/2024, we have at least 2 developers how meet this criteria, see the discussion here: https://discourse.llvm.org/t/do-you-have-secure-development-knowledge/78429/4
know_common_errors_justification: As of 4/23/2024, we have at least 2 developers how meet this criteria, see the discussion here: https://discourse.llvm.org/t/do-you-have-secure-development-knowledge/78429/4
delivery_mitm_justification:
Releases are hosted on https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases

We sign our source tarballs, but not our release binaries.
delivery_unsigned_justification: All our release assets are hosted at https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/releases which uses https.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: As of May 9, 2024, all medium or higher CVEs listed here have been fixed: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/search/results?form_type=Advanced&results_type=overview&search_type=all&isCpeNameSearch=false&cpe_vendor=cpe%3A%2F%3Allvm
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: As of May 9, 2024, according to https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/search/results?form_type=Advanced&results_type=overview&search_type=all&isCpeNameSearch=false&cpe_vendor=cpe%3A%2F%3Allvm  there have been no critical CVEs assigned to the project.
static_analysis_justification:
We are running the clang static analyzer against our main branch one per day, and we will be running it for every commit the release branches going forward.
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/actions/workflows/ci-post-commit-analyzer.yml
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: We don't currently use a static analysis tool.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: We don't currently use a static analysis tool.
static_analysis_often_justification: We don't currently use a static analysis tool.
dynamic_analysis_justification: We generally don't really much on fuzzing, because we assume that all inputs are trusted.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We have several buildbots that run tests with the sanitizers enabled: https://lab.llvm.org
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We generally don't really much on fuzzing, because we assume that all inputs are trusted.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: We generally don't really much on fuzzing, because we assume that all inputs are trusted.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: When code is merged to the main branch, there is an automated buildbot system that tests the result: https://lab.llvm.org/buildbot/#/console
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: We use https://www.passwordstore.org/ to encrypt and store our project credentials in a private git repository.
english_justification:
* Documentation in English: https://llvm.org/docs/
* Bug Reports in English: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues
* Code comments in English: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/release/17.x/clang/lib/Driver/Driver.cpp#L2524
installation_common_justification:
TODO: Fix ninja uninstall
The project use CMake to configure the build system.  Ninja install works, but ninja uninstall does not.
dco_justification: TODO: Need to clarify why we don't have one of these.
governance_justification:
LLVM decision making process: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-www/blob/main/proposals/LP0001-LLVMDecisionMaking.md
Code Owners: https://www.llvm.org/docs/DeveloperPolicy.html#code-owners
Release Managers: https://llvm.org/docs/HowToReleaseLLVM.html
roles_responsibilities_justification:
Code Owners are the only real defined role for the project:
https://llvm.org/docs/DeveloperPolicy.html#code-owners
https://clang.llvm.org/docs/CodeOwners.html

We also have project admins, but no documentation for that. TODO: Document project admin responsibilities.
bus_factor_justification: As of June 11, 2024, we have a truck factor of 71 according to https://github.com/mtov/truck-factor.
documentation_architecture_justification: TODO: Find the links for this.  I think we have this for some areas of the project.
documentation_quick_start_justification:
https://llvm.org/docs/GettingStarted.html

This provides the basics for how to build and use llvm/clang.
documentation_current_justification: We generate and host the documentation directly from the main branch in git: https://llvm.org/docs/
documentation_achievements_justification: There are OpenSSF ScoreCard and OpenSSF Best Practices badges in the README file: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: TODO: We need to check if our websites meet this criteria.
internationalization_justification: We don't translate the error or warning messages.
maintenance_or_update_justification: It's easy to download and build a new version of the compiler.  You can even install new versions along side old versions.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: TODO: I'm not sure what giving credit means.  I need to check with the security team.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: Coding style is enforced with a GitHub actions job: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/actions/workflows/pr-code-format.yml
build_standard_variables_justification: You can specify your own flags using the CMAKE_*_FLAGS variable.  These will be added to the list of internal language flags.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Debug information is preserved on install.
build_non_recursive_justification: The CMake build system correctly computes dependencies and builds the objects in the correct order.
build_repeatable_justification: TODO: Investigate how well we support reproducible builds.
installation_standard_variables_justific: TODO: Investigate if DESTDIR is supported.
installation_development_quick_justifica: I think we meet this.  There really aren't a lot of prerequisites for building the llvm-project.  For the most part, you can just download the source and build it without needing to set anything else up.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: TODO: We bundle a few things, we need to create a process for keeping them up-to-date.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: We run the test suite on every change submitted to the release/* branches.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: LLVM doesn't process passwords or other sensitive information.
version_tags_signed_justification: The project release tags are signed: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/tags
project_entry_attribution: Please credit Tom Stellard and the CII Best Practices badge contributors.
